results.title: The Tiny Carnivores
results.creator_credit: Peter Du Cane and David Moore
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fauna”.
In this huge country most of the carnivorous mammals are tiny, and many are marsupials. Typically they are small but fierce predators of insects, spiders and grubs, but some - notably the native cats and Tasmanian Devil - are larger and more formidable. The program explores the behaviour of these animals.

results.title: The Little Marsupials
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fauna”.
This program that contains rare and sometimes unique footage of little marsupials, including the amazing Honey Possum. Includes footage of the Numbats which feed exclusively on termites. Rare and endangered, the Numbats are the subject of research sponsored by the World Wildlife Fund. Features the marsupial gliders and the rare Red-Tailed Wambenger.

results.title: The Silver Gull
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fauna”.
This program shows that the Silver Gulls have a fascinating behaviour and ecology. As well as their interaction with humans, we see their beautiful off-shore island nesting grounds where thousands of birds compete for territory. Sharing this idyllic habitat with the gulls are Sea-Lions, with quaint antics on shore and graceful gymnastics in the water.

results.title: Reptiles
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fauna”.
Australia has some of the most interesting reptiles in the world. There are giant crocodiles, beautiful sea turtles and a variety of bizarre lizards, including the amazing Frilled Lizard. Even more remarkable are the snakes. Nine out of the ten most venomous snakes in the world are Australian. Included is rare footage of the recently discovered Small Scaled Snake. Narrated by David Moore.

results.title: The Remarkable bandicoots
results.creator_credit: David Moore, Peter Du Cane, Film Centre (Perth, W.A.) and Wildfilm Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fauna”.
Until 1930 the Rabbit-Eared Bandicoot, or Bilby, was relatively common in various parts of Australia but suddenly it disappeared from many of them. Today it is the subject of an intensive search and study sponsored by the World Wildlife Fund. The program investigates the history and mystery of this beautiful marsupial. Narrated by David Moore.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Moore, Peter Du Cane, Film Centre (Perth, W.A.) and Wildfilm Australia

Episode number 1 of Series “Famous women of the past”.
Historical and biographical docudrama about the life and times of Joan of Arc.

results.title: Famous women of the past
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: The Queen of Sheba
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Famous women of the past”.
Strange and dramatic pages from the lives of the world’s most famous women. The Queen of Sheba having heard of King Solomon’s wisdom, travels across the desert to Jerusalem to meet him. The journey is one of the greatest overland journeys in history. On her arrival, the King greets her with majestic splendour, cordiality and hospitality. After a six-month stay, the Queen decides to return home. Following a sumptuous banquet in her honour, King Solomon tricks the Queen and satisfies his lust for this woman of great beauty and deep intelligence. The Queen of Sheba returns home and gives birth to a son. King Soloman never sees the Queen again but does finally meet his 16 yeaer old son, who later becomes the King of Abyssinia.

results.title: Delilah
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Famous women of the past”
Aided by the art of famous painters, this documentary tells the tail of Delilah, the biblical character, outcast and lover of Samson. Victim of savage gossip, she is burnt to death by Samson’s jealous Philistines.
